abstract: Most herbivores have a very restricted host range (the specialists), but some (called generalists) include a large number of different food plants in their diet. Here, we investigate the land snail Arianta arbustorum (Helicidae) to discover whether eating several plant species is more advantageous than eating one plant species only. In the faeces of field-collected Arianta arbustorum, the plant species eaten were identified anatomically. Over 89% of the snails had eaten more than one food item within the period of 1-3 days, for which the faeces are representative. In the laboratory, Arianta arbustorum was presented with two different food plants in sequence and the amounts eaten were measured (sequentially mixed diet group)
